author: By     Silvia Ascarelli
title: This map puts America in a time warp - MarketWatch
text:
The future U.S. is going to look like Texas, New Mexico and California already look today — more Hispanic and, to a lesser extent, Asian.
While the demographic shift has long been discussed — and becomes even more pronounced ahead of every presidential election — this map from Time magazine is a cool way to see what America has been and what it will become, using 2013 Census Bureau data and projections.
Nearly 90% white, like in the 1930s? That is still Montana, North Dakota, Iowa and New Hampshire today.
The U.S. today? Closer to Illinois — 63% white.
By 2060, whites will be less than 50% of the population, as they already are in three states and almost that way in a fourth. (The Census Bureau projects the country will be 44% white and 29% Hispanic by then.) The Asian share of the population is expected to reach 9% — where it already is in New Jersey. (Overall, New Jersey’s current population is most aligned with how the U.S. as a whole will look in 2025.)
Go to Time.com to see the data behind the map.
While there’s already plenty of speculation about how that could play out politically — will Democrats gain the bulk of votes from the growing portion of Hispanic and Asian voters, or will Republicans make inroads? — the shifts are already playing out in state and local issues. For example, political pundits have said shifting demographics (including whites from out of state) made it easier for officials in South Carolina and Georgia to take down the Confederate battle flag.
